dex.name: Decentralized Exchanges
dex.explanation: DA requirements for DEXs are driven by order book updates, trade execution speed, liquidity pool rebalancing, and market dynamics. High-frequency trading, flash crashes, and large market movements can cause significant DA spikes.

metrics.name: Order Book Management

subMetrics.name: Order Placement Rate
subMetrics.ongoingExample: A popular trading pair sees 1000 new limit orders per minute, requiring frequent order book updates.
subMetrics.volatilityExample: During a market crash, order placement rate spikes to 10,000 per minute, causing a surge in DA demand.

subMetrics.name: Order Cancellation Rate
subMetrics.ongoingExample: Traders cancel about 500 orders per minute as part of regular strategy adjustments.
subMetrics.volatilityExample: A false rumor causes panic, leading to 5,000 order cancellations per minute.

subMetrics.name: Order Book Depth
subMetrics.ongoingExample: The order book maintains 1000 price levels on each side, requiring constant updates.
subMetrics.volatilityExample: Market makers add liquidity, expanding the order book to 5000 levels per side.

metrics.explanation:
Order book management DA increases due to:
• Higher frequency of order placements and cancellations
• Deeper order books requiring more data storage and updates
• Need for real-time synchronization across all nodes
• Increased complexity in maintaining order book integrity during high volatility

metrics.name: Trade Execution

subMetrics.name: Transaction Rate
subMetrics.ongoingExample: The exchange processes 100 trades per second during normal market conditions.
subMetrics.volatilityExample: A major news event causes trading volume to spike to 1000 trades per second.

subMetrics.name: Trade Size
subMetrics.ongoingExample: Average trade size is 1 ETH, requiring standard transaction data.
subMetrics.volatilityExample: Large investors enter the market, increasing average trade size to 100 ETH.

subMetrics.name: Slippage Monitoring
subMetrics.ongoingExample: Slippage is calculated every 5 seconds for active trading pairs.
subMetrics.volatilityExample: High volatility requires slippage calculations every 0.5 seconds to protect traders.

metrics.explanation:
Trade execution DA spikes due to:
• Dramatic increase in transaction volume during volatile periods
• Larger trade sizes requiring more data to process and verify
• More frequent and complex slippage calculations
• Need for faster block creation and propagation to handle increased load

metrics.name: Liquidity Pool Updates

subMetrics.name: Pool Rebalancing
subMetrics.ongoingExample: Liquidity pools rebalance every 10 minutes to maintain target ratios.
subMetrics.volatilityExample: Rapid price changes force pool rebalancing every 30 seconds.

subMetrics.name: Liquidity Provider Actions
subMetrics.ongoingExample: 50 liquidity providers adjust their positions hourly.
subMetrics.volatilityExample: A yield farming opportunity causes 500 LPs to adjust positions in minutes.

subMetrics.name: Automated Market Making
subMetrics.ongoingExample: AMM curves are updated every 100 blocks under normal conditions.
subMetrics.volatilityExample: Extreme volatility requires AMM curve updates every 10 blocks.

metrics.explanation:
Liquidity pool updates require more DA due to:
• Frequent rebalancing of pools to maintain desired ratios
• Increased liquidity provider activities (adding/removing liquidity)
• More complex and frequent automated market making calculations
• Need for real-time updates of pool states across the network

scenarios.name: Flash Crash
scenarios.description:
During a flash crash, DA requirements spike dramatically due to:
• Sudden influx of sell orders and cancellations
• Rapid price changes requiring frequent order book updates
• Potential cascading liquidations in leveraged positions
• Need for quick dissemination of market data to prevent further panic

scenarios.name: New Token Listing
scenarios.description:
A popular new token listing increases DA demand due to:
• Surge in new user registrations and KYC verifications
• High volume of initial orders populating the order book
• Rapid liquidity pool creation and initial balancing
• Increased network traffic for price discovery and initial trading

scenarios.name: High-Frequency Trading Event
scenarios.description:
HFT events cause DA spikes due to:
• Extremely high order placement and cancellation rates
• Need for nanosecond-level timestamp precision
• Increased demand for ultra-low-latency data propagation
• Complex algorithmic trading strategies requiring more computational resources

lendingBorrowing.name: Lending and Borrowing
lendingBorrowing.explanation: DA requirements for lending and borrowing protocols are driven by interest rate updates, collateral value fluctuations, and loan position changes. Market volatility and large-scale user actions can lead to sudden spikes in DA needs.

metrics.name: Interest Rate Management

subMetrics.name: Rate Calculation Frequency
subMetrics.ongoingExample: Interest rates are recalculated every 10 minutes based on utilization rates.
subMetrics.volatilityExample: During high volatility, rates are updated every 30 seconds to reflect rapid market changes.

subMetrics.name: Market Data Integration
subMetrics.ongoingExample: External price feeds are queried hourly to adjust interest rates.
subMetrics.volatilityExample: Price feeds are queried every minute during market turbulence.

subMetrics.name: User Notification System
subMetrics.ongoingExample: Users receive daily updates on their loan interest rates.
subMetrics.volatilityExample: Real-time notifications are sent for every rate change during volatile periods.

metrics.explanation:
Interest rate management DA increases due to:
• More frequent rate recalculations in volatile markets
• Integration of real-time market data from multiple sources
• Increased user notifications about rate changes
• Need for rapid propagation of new rates across the network

metrics.name: Collateral Management

subMetrics.name: Collateral Value Updates
subMetrics.ongoingExample: Collateral values are updated every 5 minutes under normal conditions.
subMetrics.volatilityExample: During market crashes, collateral values are updated every 10 seconds.

subMetrics.name: Liquidation Monitoring
subMetrics.ongoingExample: Liquidation thresholds are checked every 15 minutes for all positions.
subMetrics.volatilityExample: Continuous real-time monitoring of all positions near liquidation thresholds.

subMetrics.name: Collateral Swap Operations
subMetrics.ongoingExample: Users perform collateral swaps a few times per hour.
subMetrics.volatilityExample: Surge in collateral swaps as users rush to more stable assets.

metrics.explanation:
Collateral management DA spikes due to:
• Rapid and frequent updates of collateral asset prices
• Increased liquidation events requiring immediate action
• Higher frequency of collateral swaps and adjustments
• Need for real-time risk assessment of collateralized positions

metrics.name: Loan Position Tracking

subMetrics.name: Position Health Calculation
subMetrics.ongoingExample: Loan health is recalculated hourly for all active positions.
subMetrics.volatilityExample: Health scores are updated every 5 minutes during high volatility.

subMetrics.name: Loan Origination and Closure
subMetrics.ongoingExample: New loans and repayments are processed within 1 minute.
subMetrics.volatilityExample: Surge in new loans and emergency closures during market events.

subMetrics.name: Historical Data Management
subMetrics.ongoingExample: Loan history is compressed and archived daily.
subMetrics.volatilityExample: Increased granularity of historical data during volatile periods.

metrics.explanation:
Loan position tracking DA requirements increase due to:
• More frequent recalculation of loan health metrics
• Increased loan origination and closure activities during market events
• Need for more detailed historical data for risk assessment
• Real-time updates of user dashboards and risk management systems

scenarios.name: Market-Wide Collateral Price Drop
scenarios.description:
During a sudden drop in collateral asset prices, DA requirements spike due to:
• Continuous revaluation of all collateralized positions
• Surge in liquidation events requiring immediate processing
• Mass user actions to add collateral or close positions
• Increased demand for real-time market data and price feeds

scenarios.name: Interest Rate Policy Change
scenarios.description:
A significant change in interest rate policy increases DA demand due to:
• Recalculation of interest rates for all active loans
• Mass user notifications about the policy change
• Surge in user actions (new loans, repayments, or refinancing)
• Increased monitoring of market reaction and system stability

scenarios.name: Large-Scale Liquidation Event
scenarios.description:
A cascade of liquidations causes DA spikes due to:
• Simultaneous processing of multiple liquidation transactions
• Rapid updates of affected user positions and overall protocol state
• Increased activity in collateral asset markets
• Heightened monitoring of protocol health and liquidity

cdpAndStablecoin.name: CDPs and Stablecoins
cdpAndStablecoin.explanation: DA requirements for CDP and stablecoin systems are driven by collateral ratio management, stablecoin minting/burning activities, and complex governance decisions. Extreme market movements and large-scale user actions can cause system-wide DA spikes.

metrics.name: Collateral Ratio Management

subMetrics.name: Collateral Price Oracles
subMetrics.ongoingExample: Collateral prices are updated every 5 minutes from multiple oracles.
subMetrics.volatilityExample: Oracle updates occur every 30 seconds during high volatility.

subMetrics.name: CDP Health Monitoring
subMetrics.ongoingExample: CDP health is recalculated every 10 minutes for all positions.
subMetrics.volatilityExample: Continuous real-time monitoring of all CDPs during market turbulence.

subMetrics.name: Liquidation Engine
subMetrics.ongoingExample: Liquidation engine checks for undercollateralized CDPs every 15 minutes.
subMetrics.volatilityExample: Liquidation engine runs continuously, processing multiple liquidations simultaneously.

metrics.explanation:
Collateral ratio management DA increases due to:
• More frequent and precise oracle price updates
• Continuous recalculation of CDP health metrics
• Increased liquidation events requiring immediate action
• Need for real-time global state updates across the network

metrics.name: Stablecoin Minting/Burning

subMetrics.name: Minting Operations
subMetrics.ongoingExample: Users mint new stablecoins a few times per hour.
subMetrics.volatilityExample: Surge in minting as users seek stable assets during market downturns.

subMetrics.name: Burning Operations
subMetrics.ongoingExample: Stablecoin burning occurs periodically for CDP ratio management.
subMetrics.volatilityExample: Mass burning events during deleveraging or confidence loss scenarios.

subMetrics.name: Supply Management
subMetrics.ongoingExample: Total supply is recalculated and published hourly.
subMetrics.volatilityExample: Real-time supply updates during high minting/burning activity.

metrics.explanation:
Stablecoin minting/burning DA spikes due to:
• Increased user activity in creating or closing CDPs
• Rapid changes in stablecoin supply requiring system-wide updates
• More frequent checks and adjustments for maintaining the peg
• Need for real-time tracking of global debt ceiling and individual user limits

metrics.name: Governance and Parameters

subMetrics.name: Stability Fee Adjustments
subMetrics.ongoingExample: Stability fees are adjusted weekly through governance votes.
subMetrics.volatilityExample: Emergency fee adjustments implemented rapidly during crisis events.

subMetrics.name: Debt Ceiling Management
subMetrics.ongoingExample: Debt ceilings are reviewed and adjusted monthly.
subMetrics.volatilityExample: Real-time debt ceiling adjustments to manage system risk during volatility.

subMetrics.name: Collateral Type Onboarding
subMetrics.ongoingExample: New collateral types are added quarterly after thorough review.
subMetrics.volatilityExample: Rapid integration of safe-haven assets during market-wide instability.

metrics.explanation:
Governance and parameter updates require more DA due to:
• Implementation of complex, multi-step governance decisions
• Need for rapid parameter adjustments during market stress
• System-wide updates for new collateral types or risk parameters
• Increased monitoring and simulation of parameter impacts on system stability

scenarios.name: Stablecoin De-pegging Event
scenarios.description:
During a stablecoin de-pegging event, DA requirements spike dramatically due to:
• Continuous price feed updates from multiple oracles
• Surge in CDP adjustments, closures, and new openings
• Mass minting/burning operations to stabilize the peg
• Increased governance activities for emergency measures

scenarios.name: New Collateral Type Addition
scenarios.description:
Adding a new collateral type increases DA demand due to:
• System-wide updates to incorporate new collateral parameters
• Surge in CDP creations using the new collateral
• Increased oracle activity for pricing the new asset
• Heightened monitoring of system health with the new collateral

scenarios.name: Governance Attack Mitigation
scenarios.description:
Mitigating a governance attack causes DA spikes due to:
• Rapid implementation of emergency shutdown procedures
• Mass processing of CDP closures and collateral returns
• Increased communication and state updates to all network participants
• Continuous monitoring and counteraction of malicious activities

crossChainOperations.name: Cross-Chain Operations
crossChainOperations.explanation: DA requirements for cross-chain operations are influenced by asset transfers between chains, state synchronization challenges, and the complexity of interoperability protocols. Coordinated cross-chain activities and security incidents can lead to significant DA demand surges.

metrics.name: Asset Transfers

subMetrics.name: Transaction Verification
subMetrics.ongoingExample: Cross-chain transactions are verified every 5 minutes on average.
subMetrics.volatilityExample: Verification frequency increases to every 30 seconds during high-volume periods.

subMetrics.name: Liquidity Management
subMetrics.ongoingExample: Liquidity pools for cross-chain assets are rebalanced hourly.
subMetrics.volatilityExample: Continuous rebalancing during periods of high transfer volume.

subMetrics.name: Fee Calculation
subMetrics.ongoingExample: Transfer fees are recalculated daily based on network conditions.
subMetrics.volatilityExample: Real-time fee adjustments during congestion or attack scenarios.

metrics.explanation:
Asset transfer DA increases due to:
• Higher frequency of cross-chain transaction verifications
• Rapid updates to liquidity pools across multiple chains
• More complex fee calculations considering multi-chain conditions
• Need for real-time tracking of in-flight transactions across chains

metrics.name: State Synchronization

subMetrics.name: Block Header Relay
subMetrics.ongoingExample: Block headers are relayed between chains every 10 minutes.
subMetrics.volatilityExample: Header relay frequency increases to every block during high-activity periods.

subMetrics.name: Merkle Proof Verification
subMetrics.ongoingExample: Merkle proofs for cross-chain data are verified every 30 minutes.
subMetrics.volatilityExample: Continuous proof verification during large-scale cross-chain operations.

subMetrics.name: Consensus Mechanism Updates
subMetrics.ongoingExample: Validator set changes are propagated across chains daily.
subMetrics.volatilityExample: Rapid validator set updates during network attacks or failures.

metrics.explanation:
State synchronization DA spikes due to:
• Increased frequency of block header relays between chains
• More complex and frequent Merkle proof verifications
• Rapid propagation of consensus mechanism updates across chains
• Need for maintaining consistent state across multiple blockchain networks

metrics.name: Interoperability Protocol Management

subMetrics.name: Protocol Version Control
subMetrics.ongoingExample: Interoperability protocol versions are checked daily across all integrated chains.
subMetrics.volatilityExample: Real-time version checks and updates during critical protocol upgrades.

subMetrics.name: Cross-Chain Contract Calls
subMetrics.ongoingExample: Cross-chain smart contract calls are processed every 5 minutes.
subMetrics.volatilityExample: Continuous processing of contract calls during multi-chain DApp events.

subMetrics.name: Bridging Security Monitoring
subMetrics.ongoingExample: Security audits of bridge contracts are performed weekly.
subMetrics.volatilityExample: Continuous monitoring and real-time alerts during suspected bridge exploits.

metrics.explanation:
Interoperability protocol management DA requirements increase due to:
• Need for consistent protocol versions across multiple chains
• Increased complexity and frequency of cross-chain contract calls
• Enhanced security monitoring of bridge contracts and transactions
• Rapid response mechanisms for cross-chain security incidents

scenarios.name: Large-Scale Cross-Chain DeFi Event
scenarios.description:
During a major cross-chain DeFi event (e.g., a popular yield farming opportunity), DA requirements spike due to:
• Surge in cross-chain asset transfers and liquidity movements
• Increased frequency of state synchronization between chains
• Higher demand for real-time data about conditions on multiple chains
• Need for rapid fee adjustments to manage network congestion

scenarios.name: Interoperability Protocol Upgrade
scenarios.description:
A significant upgrade to the interoperability protocol increases DA demand due to:
• Coordinated update of protocol versions across all participating chains
• Temporary increase in state synchronization to ensure consistency
• Surge in security monitoring during and after the upgrade
• Increased user communications and state updates across chains

scenarios.name: Cross-Chain Security Incident
scenarios.description:
Managing a cross-chain security incident (e.g., a bridge exploit) causes DA spikes due to:
• Immediate freeze of cross-chain transfers and contract calls
• Rapid propagation of security alerts across all connected chains
• Intensive auditing and verification of recent cross-chain transactions
• Coordinated effort to implement emergency mitigation measures
